answers.text: Hinkley Point C nuclear power station is a project to construct a 3,200 MW two reactor nuclear power station
Stop Hinkley, was formed to campaign for the closure of Hinkley Point B and oppose any expansion at the Hinkley Point site

qas.question: What did the European Commission review

answers.text: opened an investigation to assess whether the project breaks state-aid rules

qas.question: How did the Commission vote turn out

answers.text: the European Commission has approved the project, with an overwhelming majority and only four commissioners voting against the decision.

qas.question: How powerful was the Hinkley Point A nuclear power station?
How many commissioners are on the European Commission?

context: <a0_0>Hinkley Point C nuclear power station is a project to construct a <b4_0><b6_0>3,200 MW<b6_0/><b4_0/> two reactor nuclear power station<a0_0/>. On 18 October <b8_0>2010<b8_0/>, the British government announced that Hinkley Point – already the site of the disused Hinkley Point A and the still operational Hinkley Point B power stations – was one of the eight sites it considered suitable for future nuclear power stations. NNB Generation Company, a subsidiary of EDF, submitted an application for development consent to the Infrastructure Planning Commission on 31 October <b7_0>2011<b7_0/>. A protest group, <a1_0>Stop Hinkley, was formed to campaign for the closure of Hinkley Point B and oppose any expansion at the Hinkley Point site<a1_0/>. In December 2013, the European Commission <a2_0>opened an investigation to assess whether the project breaks state-aid rules<a2_0/>. On 8 October 2014 it was announced that <a3_0>the European Commission has approved the project, with an overwhelming majority and only <b5_0>four<b5_0/> commissioners voting against the decision.
